ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Generally, crime and punishment: policing, lawyers and the court system, cities and how they differentiate in C&P.

I gained so much knowledge about the intricacies of the criminal legal system include the effects of pre-arrest factors that may contribute to crime and how the post-carceral re-entry policies can affect those not directly touched by the system.
I learned a great foundation of knowledge about the american criminal justice system and its flaws.
I learned how to think critically about the root problems of the U.S. criminal justice system.
I learned about the nuances of how perceptions of crime is constructed and how crime affects and shapes cities.

i learned a wide array of information about our criminal justice system while learning it in an urban context. i strengthened my writing and was able to gain a wider understanding of how our country operates through our legal system
This course has expanded my knowledge on the many social and equality issues in our society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: If you have great classmates, you will have a great discussion. Weakness: Professor was very busy with her child and we had to end class early/take half hour breaks almost every class. Hopefully this will not be the case next time.

Professor Harris is incredibly thorough in explaining assignments and providing feedback. Her class had a good balance of lecture instruction and student-led presentations that allowed students to freely discuss and bounce ideas off of each other.

strengths: applicable and relevant topic, interesting readings
weakness: course almost completely based on students presenting readings and there is minimal formal lecture from the professor. I feel like a lot more information could have been learned through lectures instead of people presenting on the readings everyone has already read.

The readings were all pretty interesting, and the studies showed interesting findings of the effects of incarceration on individuals from many different angles. Professor Harris was really understanding about class through Zoom, so that was nice. Most of the class is just student presentations, and I'm not sure how helpful that format was.

Strength: The material is super interesting and Prof. Harris is amazing! Prof. Harris created a very thoughtful syllabus. We got to learn a lot about crime and from various lenses, from narrative readings to more empirical/historical studies.
Weakness: Most of the class is just students presenting. I think it would be more engaging if more time was given towards just discussion instead of students presenting the readings.

i think the format of the class was great especially having breaks in between since the class was quite long. One thing that could be improved would be to maybe incorporate more activities besides presentations in class.

I liked the presentation aspect of the course as a solid way to keep everyone engaged with the content, but a major downside was the length of class. We often found ourselves with too much time than we knew what to deal with in the 3 hours, and I think a 2 hour class would be more than enough.
I liked the number of people in the class it was not too many and not too little

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you want an easy A. Gwen is amazing at helping you with your assignments and really there for you. Professor Harris is also great, but she was very busy and occupied with her child. Never seems to be active in our discussions (which pretty much is 90% of the class).

Absolutely! this course provides so much information about the criminal legal system and presents alternative points of view through the readings so students can view an issue from multiple angles and formulate their opinions through rigorous discussion.
I would definitely recommend if youre interested in the criminal justice system and how it disproportionally targets minority communities. The workload is very manageable and the professor is great!

YES! Especially if you are interested in prison reform. All of the readings were insightful and interesting, and Professor harris does a good job of providing background in the first couple of classes. The workload was pretty light (besides the readings), so I would highly recommend!
Yes
Yes! This is a great course to get a historical and empirical overview of how crime intersects with race, politics, and urban landscapes.
yes absolutely! this course is great and the professor is incredible! I think the topics of conversation are incredibly interesting and engaging!
yes, it was very interesting and changed my view on society and how much racial injustice there is.
